docs.lead_paragraph: Her standing among Democrats was far weaker eight years ago than it is today, based on polls and on the actions of other potential candidates.
docs.abstract: The Upshot; discussion of Hillary Rodham Clinton as likely Democratic nominee for president in 2016 often prompts recollection that she failed to secure nomination in 2008, despite being frontrunner then; comparison to 2008 is flawed due to upgrade in Clinton's stature in Democratic Party over course of last 8 years and, based on polls and actions of other possible candidates, she has never been stronger.

headline.main: Hillary Clinton and Inevitability: This Time Is Different

docs.lead_paragraph: Mickey Mouse has deep pockets when it comes to Hillary Rodham Clinton. Walt Disney executives and their families donated $56,500 to Mrs. Clinton's Senate campaign, more than any other company. But as an industry, the legal profession topped the list of donors, giving Mrs. Clinton, a Yale Law School graduate, $666,879, according to an analysis of her campaign filing by the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonpartisan research organization. The entertainment industry was next, donating $439,740.
docs.abstract: Center for Responsive Politics analysis finds that Walt Disney executives and their families donated $56,500 to Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign, more than any other company; finds that legal profession gave Mrs Clinton $666,879 and entertainment industry donated $439,740 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Future demand for high-tech skills should compel Hispanic students to push for greater educational achievement, Hillary Rodham Clinton, the First Lady, told the nation's largest Hispanic civil rights group. ''The 21st century will be ruthless,'' Mrs. Clinton said on Monday in a speech to the National Council of La Raza at its conference here.
docs.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton addresses National Council of La Raza, nation's largest Hispanic civil-rights group, saying future demand for high-tech skills should compel Hispanic students to push for greater educational achievement; deplores statistics showing that nearly one-third of all Hispanic students drop out of high school (M)
